title: Partial ceasefire set to have limited effect on gas prices
subtitle: (Montel) Russia’s agreement to halt attacks on Ukrainian energy infrastructure for 30 days was not enough to have a significant bearish impact on European gas markets, analysts told Montel on Wednesday.
body:
Russian president Vladimir Putin agreed to immediately suspend attacks on Ukraine’s energy infrastructure late on Tuesday, following talks with his US counterpart Donald Trump.
Since the announcement, attacks on civilian Ukrainian infrastructure – including an energy substation in the Donetsk region – have been reported, and Russian authorities have said a Ukrainian drone attack damaged an oil depot in the country’s Krasnodar region.
“The fact that we are not seeing a proper ceasefire is tending to push prices slightly higher,” said Mike Fulwood, senior research fellow at the Oxford Institute for Energy Studies, although he noted that “TTF prices always go up first thing in the morning then reverse”.
The benchmark front-month TTF gas contract was last seen trading up by EUR 2.48 at EUR 43.24/MWh.
Most analysts contacted by Montel said the price movement was not necessarily linked to the geopolitical situation, although one gas market expert said the increase was due to “disappointment” at the outcome of the Trump-Putin call.
“One would hope for more than a temporary energy ceasefire,” said Klaas Dozeman, analyst at Brainchild Commodity Intelligence.
No significant changes“A 30-day ceasefire is good, it might open up discussions and help to assess the direction in which [the conflict] is heading, but it won’t lead to significant changes” on gas markets, said Anne-Sophie Corbeau, a Columbia University research scholar.
The timeframe and limited scope of the ceasefire was too short for any substantial impact on gas volumes, she said, although it could “ease some of the nervousness in the market”.
An enduring ceasefire could possibly lead to the lifting of US sanctions, including on Russia’s newly built Arctic LNG 2 facility, which would have a bearish impact on European gas prices, said Fulwood, although “it would take months to get [the facility] up and running”.
“There is not enough gas coming to Europe, markets are tight. If we suddenly see sanctions on Arctic LNG 2 being lifted or significantly reduced, we would have an extra 9 bcm on the market,” Corbeau said, adding that “markets would definitely react” in a bearish way to such a development.
Too naive?However, the gas market expert described expectations of a return of Russian gas flows to Europe as “naive”. Resuming transit flows through Ukraine would be “quite difficult to sell in terms of internal politics”, he said, while the use of the Nord Stream 2 pipeline would hit regulatory and legal hurdles.
“Ultimately the question is whether European buyers would like to buy Russian gas, and I think in most countries there is limited appetite for that,” he said, adding that gas markets would likely ease in 2026-27 with the arrival of new LNG capacity.
“I cannot yet see the transit of Russian gas [resuming] via Ukraine in the foreseeable future,” said Marina Tsygankova, director of global gas and LNG at LSEG.
Ukrainian productionA halt in bombings of Ukrainian energy infrastructure could also lead the country to require less gas imports from Europe, Tsygankova said.
The gas market expert previously cited said Ukraine was likely to need more gas imports from the EU to refill its storage units this summer, due to damage sustained by its gas production units that would take time to repair.
Currently, the main gas flows to Ukraine are from Slovakia, Hungary and – to a lesser extent – Poland, he said.
Ukrainian gas storage was last seen at just 3.7% full, according to Gas Infrastructure Europe.
